► Below are some important terms for academic research.

► Match the term to its definition.

data.template: The flow of international students is defined as the movement from one country to another in order to receive an education at any level (UNESCO, 2015). Tremblay (2005) points out that studies of this area focus on push and pull factors, in other words, the reasons that motivate students to study abroad. Pull factors are positive reasons that international education offers; such as prestige, flexibility and facilities (Mazzarol & Soutar, 2002). Whereas push factors are issues “within the students home country that initiate the student’s decision to study overseas” (Wilkins, 2012, p. 3). These factors are usually the negative of pull factors, for example: lack of prestige, lack of flexibility and lower quality facilities. An understanding of these factors is key to understanding and trying to manage the overall flow students.
data.stimulus:
Using Sources

Review the extract from an article about "International Student Flow" and answer the questions. 

 

1. Highlight the in-text citations.
2. How many quotations are used in the text?
3. How many paraphrases are used in the text?

4. Review the table below.
The first column shows the source in the text - the other columns show how the source is used.
Is the source quoted? Paraphrased? Does it use a reporting verb?
Choose the correct options.

In-text Citations: Format

 

Citations must contain certain features and those features must be in the correct order. Review the examples below and drag and drop your answers to create accurate citations. 

 

1. This citation is for a paraphrase and is used after the source
2. This citation is for a quotation and is used before the source.
3. This citation is for a paraphrase and is used before the source.
4. This citation is for a quotation and is used after the source.

Let's analyse the difference between a paraphrase and a quotation.

 

 

 

 

 

 

► You can find all the information about APA referencing in your APA Referencing Short Guide (in your OneNote Class Notebook, in the section Class Library)
data.template:
{{response}}: To say the same idea in different words.
{{response}}: To say the same idea in the same words.  
  • You should use quotes for {{response}} sentences only. 
  • You must use {{response}} at the beginning and the end of the quote.​​​​
Page numbers in in-text citations: 
  • The in-text citation of a paraphrase {{response}} include page numbers.
  • The in-text citation of a quotation {{response}} include page numbers.
Example:
  • (Jackson 2020, p25) → This is the {{response}}
  • (Jackson 2020) → This is the {{response}}

stems: You want to show you understand the main ideas of the author
The original wording is strong and engaging
You want to present specific ideas or claims of the author
You summarise information which matches your own ideas
You need to simplify complex ideas
You need to be accurate (in under 10 words!)

data.stimulus:
When paraphrasing, we need to use synonyms (words with similar meanings) in order to be academic

Consider the paragraph below. 

  • Match the underlined phrases to their synonyms (choose form the drop down).

 

An essential (1) skill for the majority of (2) teams, continuous improvement is the process of learning from unfavourable outcomes (3) and implementing (4) new strategies to achieve (5) better results. Although continuous improvement has proven to be a difficult (6) tactic (7) to master, once you achieve it, it is an extremely (8) effective (9) skill that can be implemented in almost any environment (10) (Kastner 2018).

6. difficult - {{response}}
7. tactic - {{response}}
8.extremelly - {{response}}
9. effective - {{response}}
10. environment - {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Next, we are going to EVALUATE some paraphrases - did the writer paraphrase EFFECTIVELY?

 

Read the original sources and paraphrases below. 

  • Which is the best paraphrase?

 

 

Paraphrase 1 (the paragraph above) 

Original Source:

An essential skill for the majority of teams, continuous improvement is the process of learning from negative experiences and implementing new strategies to strive to achieve better results. Although continuous improvement has proven to be a difficult tactic to master, once you achieve it, it is an extremely effective skill that can be implemented in almost any environment.
data.template: The best paraphrase is {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Paraphrase 2

Original source:

Intercultural cooperation is an ideal tool for managing the increasingly complex processes we face in the workplace today because good international teamwork is more than the sum of each member's input. Ideally, each team member will have their own role to play while the team manager coordinates the project and monitors its progress (Kastner 2018).
data.template: The best paraphrase is {{response}}

data.stimulus:
Paraphrase 3 

Original source:

As technology constantly improves, the world of work is becoming truly international. Modern collaborative software and communication tools have made it easier than ever to run a completely international team. These can be hugely beneficial but has its own challenges. Overcoming some of the natural obstacles that coordinating an international team represents takes time, effort and understanding but in the long run will be well worth it (Kastner 2018).
data.template: The best paraphrase is {{response}}
